title: HW2_Base_R
text:
Create two vectors. One vector corresponding to the pre measurements and one to the post measurements.
Assign names to the vector elements using the paste() function.

pre_treatment <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)

post_treatment <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)

patient_names <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")

names(pre_treatment) <- patient_names
names(post_treatment) <- patient_names


pre_treatment

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       120        151        125        126        115        132        132 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       129        134        139        127        122        127        135 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       133        128        147        138        140        132 



post_treatment

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       127        145        135        122        115        122        123 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       126        126        129        132        146        120        114 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       121        120        128        120        133        115 


Calculate the change in blood pressure for each patient by subtracting post-treatment measurements from pre-treatment measurements.

bp_change <- pre_treatment - post_treatment
bp_change

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
        -7          6        -10          4          0         10          9 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
         3          8         10         -5        -24          7         21 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
        12          8         19         18          7         17 


Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure across all patients

mean_change <- mean(bp_change)
mean_change

[1] 5.65


Determine which patients experienced a decrease in blood pressure after treatment (a positive change). Use the which() function to just return the indices (and names) associated with this type of change.

patients_with_decrease <- which(bp_change > 0)

patients_with_decrease_names <- names(bp_change)[patients_with_decrease]

patients_with_decrease_names

 [1] "Subject_2"  "Subject_4"  "Subject_6"  "Subject_7"  "Subject_8" 
 [6] "Subject_9"  "Subject_10" "Subject_13" "Subject_14" "Subject_15"
[11] "Subject_16" "Subject_17" "Subject_18" "Subject_19" "Subject_20"


Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change.

bp_decreased <- bp_change[bp_change > 0]

bp_decreased

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         6          4         10          9          3          8         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
         7         21         12          8         19         18          7 
Subject_20 
        17 


Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those where the blood pressure decreased (positive change).

mean_bp_decrease <- mean(bp_decreased)

mean_bp_decrease

[1] 10.6

title: HW2_Base_R
text:
Create two vectors. One vector corresponding to the pre measurements and one to the post measurements.
Assign names to the vector elements using the paste() function.

pre_treatment <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)

post_treatment <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)

patient_names <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")

names(pre_treatment) <- patient_names
names(post_treatment) <- patient_names


pre_treatment

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       120        151        125        126        115        132        132 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       129        134        139        127        122        127        135 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       133        128        147        138        140        132 



post_treatment

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       127        145        135        122        115        122        123 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       126        126        129        132        146        120        114 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       121        120        128        120        133        115 


Calculate the change in blood pressure for each patient by subtracting post-treatment measurements from pre-treatment measurements.

bp_change <- pre_treatment - post_treatment
bp_change

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
        -7          6        -10          4          0         10          9 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
         3          8         10         -5        -24          7         21 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
        12          8         19         18          7         17 


Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure across all patients

mean_change <- mean(bp_change)
mean_change

[1] 5.65


Determine which patients experienced a decrease in blood pressure after treatment (a positive change). Use the which() function to just return the indices (and names) associated with this type of change.

patients_with_decrease <- which(bp_change > 0)

patients_with_decrease_names <- names(bp_change)[patients_with_decrease]

patients_with_decrease_names

 [1] "Subject_2"  "Subject_4"  "Subject_6"  "Subject_7"  "Subject_8" 
 [6] "Subject_9"  "Subject_10" "Subject_13" "Subject_14" "Subject_15"
[11] "Subject_16" "Subject_17" "Subject_18" "Subject_19" "Subject_20"


Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change.

bp_decreased <- bp_change[bp_change > 0]

bp_decreased

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         6          4         10          9          3          8         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
         7         21         12          8         19         18          7 
Subject_20 
        17 


Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those where the blood pressure decreased (positive change).

mean_bp_decrease <- mean(bp_decreased)

mean_bp_decrease

[1] 10.6

title: HW2_Base_R
text:
Task 2: Basic Data Frame Practice
Create a data frame object with four columns corresponding to your data above:

patient
pre_bp
post_bp
diff_bp


bp_df <- data.frame(
  patient = patient_names,
  pre_bp = pre_treatment,
  post_bp = post_treatment,
  diff_bp = pre_treatment - post_treatment
)

bp_df

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
Subject_1   Subject_1    120     127      -7
Subject_2   Subject_2    151     145       6
Subject_3   Subject_3    125     135     -10
Subject_4   Subject_4    126     122       4
Subject_5   Subject_5    115     115       0
Subject_6   Subject_6    132     122      10
Subject_7   Subject_7    132     123       9
Subject_8   Subject_8    129     126       3
Subject_9   Subject_9    134     126       8
Subject_10 Subject_10    139     129      10
Subject_11 Subject_11    127     132      -5
Subject_12 Subject_12    122     146     -24
Subject_13 Subject_13    127     120       7
Subject_14 Subject_14    135     114      21
Subject_15 Subject_15    133     121      12
Subject_16 Subject_16    128     120       8
Subject_17 Subject_17    147     128      19
Subject_18 Subject_18    138     120      18
Subject_19 Subject_19    140     133       7
Subject_20 Subject_20    132     115      17


Return only rows of the data frame where the diff_bp column is negative. (Use [ or learn about the subset() function if you’d like. If you use [, don’t reference the original vector from the first part, access the column of the data frame to make your comparison with 0.)

negative_diff_rows <- bp_df[bp_df$diff_bp < 0, ]

negative_diff_rows

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
Subject_1   Subject_1    120     127      -7
Subject_3   Subject_3    125     135     -10
Subject_11 Subject_11    127     132      -5
Subject_12 Subject_12    122     146     -24



negative_diff_rows_subset <- subset(bp_df, diff_bp < 0)

negative_diff_rows_subset

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
Subject_1   Subject_1    120     127      -7
Subject_3   Subject_3    125     135     -10
Subject_11 Subject_11    127     132      -5
Subject_12 Subject_12    122     146     -24


Add a new column to the data frame corresponding to TRUE if the post_bp is less than 120 and FALSE if it is not. Similar to the previous question, don’t reference the original vector from task 1, access the column of the data frame to make your comparison

bp_df$below_120 <- bp_df$post_bp < 120

bp_df

              patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp below_120
Subject_1   Subject_1    120     127      -7     FALSE
Subject_2   Subject_2    151     145       6     FALSE
Subject_3   Subject_3    125     135     -10     FALSE
Subject_4   Subject_4    126     122       4     FALSE
Subject_5   Subject_5    115     115       0      TRUE
Subject_6   Subject_6    132     122      10     FALSE
Subject_7   Subject_7    132     123       9     FALSE
Subject_8   Subject_8    129     126       3     FALSE
Subject_9   Subject_9    134     126       8     FALSE
Subject_10 Subject_10    139     129      10     FALSE
Subject_11 Subject_11    127     132      -5     FALSE
Subject_12 Subject_12    122     146     -24     FALSE
Subject_13 Subject_13    127     120       7     FALSE
Subject_14 Subject_14    135     114      21      TRUE
Subject_15 Subject_15    133     121      12     FALSE
Subject_16 Subject_16    128     120       8     FALSE
Subject_17 Subject_17    147     128      19     FALSE
Subject_18 Subject_18    138     120      18     FALSE
Subject_19 Subject_19    140     133       7     FALSE
Subject_20 Subject_20    132     115      17      TRUE

title: HW2_Base_R
text:
Task 3: List Practice
Create a new data frame with the given placebo data in it that is similar to the data frame from task 2 (including the new column of TRUE/FALSE values).

pre_treatment_placebo <- c(138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130)
post_treatment_placebo <- c(105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124)

subject_names_placebo <- paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_")

placebo_df <- data.frame(
  patient = subject_names_placebo,
  pre_bp = pre_treatment_placebo,
  post_bp = post_treatment_placebo,
  diff_bp = pre_treatment_placebo - post_treatment_placebo,
  below_120 = pre_treatment_placebo < 120
)

placebo_df

      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp below_120
1   Subject_1    138     105      33     FALSE
2   Subject_2    135     136      -1     FALSE
3   Subject_3    147     123      24     FALSE
4   Subject_4    117     130     -13      TRUE
5   Subject_5    152     134      18     FALSE
6   Subject_6    134     143      -9     FALSE
7   Subject_7    114     135     -21      TRUE
8   Subject_8    121     139     -18     FALSE
9   Subject_9    131     120      11     FALSE
10 Subject_10    130     124       6     FALSE


Now create and store a list with two elements:

1st element named treatment and contains the first data frame you created.
2nd element named placebo and contains the second data frame you created.


experiment_list <- list(
  treatment = bp_df,
  placebo = placebo_df
)

str(experiment_list)

List of 2
 $ treatment:'data.frame':  20 obs. of  5 variables:
  ..$ patient  : chr [1:20] "Subject_1" "Subject_2" "Subject_3" "Subject_4" ...
  ..$ pre_bp   : num [1:20] 120 151 125 126 115 132 132 129 134 139 ...
  ..$ post_bp  : num [1:20] 127 145 135 122 115 122 123 126 126 129 ...
  ..$ diff_bp  : num [1:20] -7 6 -10 4 0 10 9 3 8 10 ...
  ..$ below_120: logi [1:20] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE FALSE ...
 $ placebo  :'data.frame':  10 obs. of  5 variables:
  ..$ patient  : chr [1:10] "Subject_1" "Subject_2" "Subject_3" "Subject_4" ...
  ..$ pre_bp   : num [1:10] 138 135 147 117 152 134 114 121 131 130
  ..$ post_bp  : num [1:10] 105 136 123 130 134 143 135 139 120 124
  ..$ diff_bp  : num [1:10] 33 -1 24 -13 18 -9 -21 -18 11 6
  ..$ below_120: logi [1:10] FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE FALSE FALSE ...


Access the first list element using different types of syntax (the result can be a list or just the data frame).

experiment_list$placebo$pre_bp
